children.subject: Please use page breaks so we all can read this better.

history.content:
Regarding EE16A and B, it is theoretically possible to take them concurrently. However, I personally recommend taking them in sequence. The sequence was designed just that way - a sequence. CS61C will give you a touch of the top of the circuit stack, being digital design and microarchitecture, so you will at least have that.

If your math is strong, you can potentially take EE120. The class is largely math and a fairly fundamental class. I know of people who have taken it before EE16AB. The same goes for EE126 (though you probably should take CS70 first).

I can't really recommend taking any upper div circuits classes (e.g. 105) without taking EE16AB. AP Physics simply does not give you enough circuits intuition to skip directly to 105. If you've completed Physics 7B, you could potentially take EE130, which is more about device physics, i.e. the physics of modern transistors, but it will be heavy without prior experience.

It is not recommended to take EE16B before 16A nor is it recommended to take them concurrently. Is summer an option for you? EE16A will be offered in summer and taking 16B in fall will put you off-cycle, which could help with getting into that class.

Hi all, I'm a second-year undeclared but CS-intended (declaring this semester) student. I would really like to take EE16A next semester because I wasn't able to get into the class these past few semesters. The problem is that I'm starting to feeling apprehensive about missing out on getting into the course yet again, which would really make it difficult for me to keep on track with my course plan. I have seen on Piazza that there won't be an expansion of EE16A this semester and since the course and waitlist are both filling up very quickly, I will try to add myself to the waitlist the second my Phase I appointment opens up tomorrow afternoon. In light of this, I'm trying to think of some other alternatives I can pursue in a worst-case scenario. After this semester I will have completed the CS lower division courses (except for 61C) and all the math lower division courses. I've also completed both AP Physics Cs in high school and I would consider myself someone with strong mathematical maturity. What I'm looking to get is an introduction to EE now as I'm afraid that if I'm unable to get into EE16A this coming spring, I won't have the time to explore other upper-division courses. For example, I know that EE16B has EE16A listed as a pre-requisite, but does anyone know if I can take EE16B before EE16A anyways so that I don't have to keep pushing it off? Or is it possible for me to take them concurrently? Not getting into EE16A now would also mean that I'll likely have to wait at least a year after starting EE16A (ideally by next fall?) before I may have the chance to explore the upper division EE courses. If I am not mistaken, I can't find any lower-division EE courses other than EE16A and EE16B that are offered by the department and many of the other courses I've checked like EE105, EE117, EE120, etc. all have EE16B listed as a pre-requisite. I'm wondering if there are any other good introductory EE courses that I may be able to enroll in to get myself acquainted with the material that are upper division or outside the EE department (this could possibly make it easier for me to take EE16A as well). Basically, for now, I will hope for the best which would be getting into EE16A this semester, but I also want to look for the best alternate plan of action to take in case I can't get in. Thanks!
history.subject: Intro to EE courses other than EE16A/B?
